Sentencas: This paper describes calculations of the electrical losses in patterned series-connected solid oxide fuel cells (SOFCs), i.e. the segmented-in-series configuration.
Titulo: Design considerations for segmented-in-series fuel cells

Sentencas: Losses due to cell resistances, electrode ohmic resistances, interconnect resistance, and shunting by a weakly-conductive support material were considered.
Titulo: Design considerations for segmented-in-series fuel cells

Sentencas: For any given set of cell dimensions and characteristics, power density was maximized at an optimal cell length - the power decreased at larger cell lengths due to electrode lateral resistance loss and decreased at smaller cell lengths due to a decreasing fraction of cell active area.
Titulo: Design considerations for segmented-in-series fuel cells

Sentencas: For cell lengths well above the optimal value, electrolyte current was often confined to the portion of the cell nearest to where the less conductive electrode (i.e. the cathode) connected to the interconnect.
Titulo: Design considerations for segmented-in-series fuel cells

Sentencas: Assuming dimensions expected for screen printing, i.e. approximate to 20 mu m thick electrodes and lateral print accuracy of approximate to 100 mu m, and area specific resistance values typical of SOFCs, optimal cell lengths typically ranged from 1 to 3 turn.
Titulo: Design considerations for segmented-in-series fuel cells

Sentencas: Shunting currents increased with decreasing cell lengths, but were found to have little effect on power density assuming partially-stabilized zirconia supports and temperatures <= 800 degrees C. (c) 2005
Titulo: Design considerations for segmented-in-series fuel cells
Design considerations for segmented-in-series fuel cells
